questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language, which is the standard markup language for creating web pages.

questions.question: Which HTML element is used to define the title of a document?
questions.explanation: The <title> tag in HTML is used to define the title of the document, which appears in the browser's title bar or tab.

questions.question: What is the correct HTML for creating a hyperlink?
questions.explanation: The correct HTML for creating a hyperlink is Link text. The href attribute specifies the destination URL.

questions.question: Which HTML5 element is used for playing video files?
questions.explanation: The <video> element is used to embed video content in an HTML document. It was introduced in HTML5.

questions.question: What is the correct HTML for inserting an image?
questions.explanation: The correct HTML for inserting an image is . The alt attribute provides alternative text for screen readers.

questions.question: Which HTML attribute is used to define inline styles?
questions.explanation: The style attribute is used to add inline CSS styles to HTML elements.

questions.question: What is the correct HTML for creating a drop-down list?
questions.explanation: The <select> element is used to create a drop-down list, with <option> elements defining the available options.

questions.question: Which HTML5 element is used to draw graphics on a web page?
questions.explanation: The <canvas> element is used to draw graphics, on the fly, via JavaScript. It's part of HTML5.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the HTML5 <article> element?
options: To define a section of navigation links
To define self-contained content that could exist independently
To define a section in a document
questions.explanation: The <article> element specifies independent, self-contained content that should make sense on its own.

questions.question: Which HTML5 element is used to define a header for a document or section?
questions.explanation: The <header> element represents a container for introductory content or a set of navigational links.
